content.description: This is the west-facing line on the prominent quartzite outcrop just across the hollow from the main crag. A great line for beginners and satisfying warm-up for those seeking the more difficult lines available at the crag. Belay from a good ledge, well-protected by the 1st bolt. Climb the low-angle quality quartzite face to the top of the crag. This line is shaded through mid-morning and offers amazing views of the valley and the wellsvilles.
content.location: From the main crag, follow a trail to the northwest around the quartzite outcrop onto the belay ledge.

content.description: Climb a slab to the bottom of the prominent crack. Use good holds within the crack and on the adjacent face to reach the chains.
content.protection: #2 to #4 sized gear, chain anchors, take care to not damage your rope on the sharp arete to the left of the route as you lower or in the event of a fall.
content.location: Around the corner and west of the main crag.

content.description: This climb features gorgeous pockets on consistent gently overhung limestone. The movements are clean and holds right where you need them. The line is what indoor route setters strive to imitate in their craft.
content.location: Middle of the main crag. Look for the prominent water streak.

content.description: This is the left-most route on the main overhung shaded sport wall. It consists of steep pocketed climbing with fun, consistent, and flowing moves. Several of the pockets are a little sharp. While stemming across to the adjacent wall is not technically forbidden, most climbers will wish to enjoy this as a face route. The crux move is high, so stemming does not affect the rating.
content.location: Start next to the chimney. Climb the east-most route on the slightly overhung, pocketed wall.

climbs.name: Acne Scars of an Adolescent Princess

content.description: Ascend the steep unique features to the right of the bolt line which including jugs, flakes, pockets, pillars and horns.
content.location: Start on the ramp on the right side of the main crag and climb up the overhung arete.
